ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of virtual seminar and other discussion format
The course was a hybrid seminar. Those able and willing to meet in-person physically attended classes while the rest joined virtually.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I further explored my study of typography, refined my design method, and thought more deeply about the ideas I want to communicate in my work. I also learned to think more critically about my classmates' work (in a good way) and form stronger opinions about the design I see in the world.
I refined my skills as a graphic designer by creating three projects (a series of posters, a pamphlet/booklet, and a looping gif around a theme.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I liked the hybrid online/in-person format. I also thought that given the pandemic conditions, Julian made a great effort to include every student and give everyone a semi-normal classroom experience. 
Weaknesses: This class goes over time anywhere from 10-40 minutes every single class, which is a disrespect of the students' time and honestly exhausting given how long we're staring at a screen. 
Furthermore, this is my fourth design class at this point where the assignments have been nearly identical to other design classes: poster, book, and then some sort of digital media like video or web. It's really repetitive from an academic standpoint and while it's true that the assignments are never exactly the same each time and that practice is helpful, it might be more productive to explore a wider range of assignments, maybe using wildly different media or encouraging us to make design objects rather than books.

Strengths: Manageable workload, clear feedback. Weaknesses: Not a lot of opportunities for input from other students during critiques, classes often ran over time. Ways to improve: Make room for student comments, be more mindful of time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I thought that the set-up with the dual cameras was very effective, and replicated being in a normal design classroom well. I appreciated the effort Julian put into making it work for everyone. 

However, also don't think that people should have been expected to come in to class if they weren't comfortable (rather than being on a set schedule). Some more flexibility would have been appreciated.

The course let people who wanted to receive in-person instruction a safe option to do so while allowing others to join virtually and not feel left out. Julian had multiple cameras set up in the classroom so everyone could see the work being discussed.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would, but I would also want them to know this: this class and most other design classes are pretty much interchangeable. It makes no difference which one you take really and had I known about the assignments beforehand, I may not have opted for this class and instead just taken ART 469 in the spring. 
Julian is a good professor but not the most helpful instructor for me personally, and I don't feel like I gained much additional insight from the class besides working on the projects, whereas I would've liked some more guidance when it came to technical design skills or design history. 
Also, I hope this is changed in future iterations fo the class, but the expectations of producing physical printed work during the pandemic was simply unreasonable. This was such a missed opportunity to teach us to adapt to an online-friendly world!
Yes. You get to use the skills youve been refining in previous graphic design classes to take familiar projects (posters, a book, an animated video) to the next level.
